awd_abstract_narration:
Advanced manufacturing industries are vital to the global competitiveness of the United States.  As a result, community colleges must work collaboratively with industry partners to develop associate degrees and certifications that educate technicians to support these industries.  To meet the needs of growing regional industries such as Forum Energy, Halliburton, Cleco, and Data Communications, this project is designed to provide industry-recognized credentials to students through the Certified Production Technicians curriculum and examinations. These credentials will be combined with the hands-on experiences needed to be successful in a competitive labor market. The project aims to prepare both faculty and students for these examinations and to produce graduates who are Certified Production Technicians.  This certification has the potential to reduce initial training time and hiring cost for employers. Graduates with Certified Production Technician certification will have knowledge about the most recent safety issues and solutions, making them more competitive for available jobs. Rigorous evaluation methods, data, and feedback will inform continuous project improvements and program enhancements through the implementation period. Recruitment efforts will target students who are underrepresented in production technician careers. 

This project aims to prepare more students to complete Certified Production Technician certification, as well as to earn a Technical Diploma, Associate of Applied Science in Industrial Electronics Technology, or Associate of Science in Industrial Technology. During the project, the college will modify and offer revised manufacturing courses to include Certified Production Technician curriculum; provide professional development for faculty so that they can become Manufacturing Skill Standards Council-authorized trainers; and hold advisory committee meetings with industry partners to increase awareness of technician industry-based credentials and receive continuous feedback of the implementation results. Manufacturing Skill Standards Council-authorized faculty will prepare students for tests in four areas: 1) Safety; 2) Quality Practices & Measurement; 3) Manufacturing Processes & Production; and 4) Maintenance Awareness. The project will adapt the best practices of other community colleges that have implemented similar curriculum changes. In turn, the project will strive to serve as a model program for other community college manufacturing programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this NSF ATE project were to expand and enhance technician training in the South Louisiana region, to meet local and statewide demands, and build capacity for workforce training. This project has allowed South Louisiana Community College (SLCC) to increase stackable industry credentials by revamping current curriculum to fill workforce needs. The project achieved its identified outcomes by implementing Industry-Based Certifications (IBCs) and expanded stackable industry credentials into the Industrial Technology and Industrial Electronics Technology programs. The project enabled students to earn certifications in Safety, Quality, Manufacturing, and Maintenance Awareness through the nationally recognized Manufacturing Skills Standard Council (MSSC) to meet industry demand for employees. Both programs successfully recruited students underrepresented in technician education. Both programs also received up-to-date equipment (Skill Boss Trainer) related to the Certified Production Technician (CPT) certification. SLCC integrated certification testing costs into program tuition and became an approved testing center qualified to conduct on-site testing for Certified Production Technician Certifications. 

The faculty received professional development for the curriculum on Safety, Quality, Manufacturing, and Maintenance Awareness. Beyond the five faculty already trained in full or in part, SLCC is training new faculty for the Certified Production Technician (SPT) certification and the Certified Logistics Technician (CLT).  These industry-based certifications are online software modules and will enable the college to expand stackable credential offerings to dually enrolled students in all rural parishes. 

Industry Advisory Committee members continue to be supportive of this program and believe the experience of obtaining certifications will lead to a more knowledgeable and skilled workforce as well as will make a job candidate more competitive when compared to other candidates without certifications. The program has also resulted in industry partnership expansion from (seven total but two new) companies partnered with SLCC to provide students internships, scholarships, tours, and full-time employment opportunities. 

With the success of a community college implementing CPT into program curriculum, MSSC requested the College to host a CPT 4.0 webinar during Spring 2022.  Principal Investigator Tanya St. Julien shared the benefits of CPT certifications for students and the industry as well as future initiatives to provide opportunities for dually enrolled students to complete certifications. 

Overall, the program has resulted in 44 students earning the Safety Certification, 21 students earning the Quality Certification, 18 students earning the Manufacturing Production Processes certification, and 14 students earning the Maintenance Awareness certification. A total of 14 students are now fully Certified Production Technicians (completing parts 1- 4), while 97 students earned individual certifications amongst the four certification classes. More specifically, 20 students earned one of four certifications, nine students earned two of four certifications, two students earned three of four certifications, and 14 students earned all four certifications. Certifications will remain embedded in the curriculum for past students to access and complete any remaining certifications at any time, while new students will continue earning the certifications as part of the program courses.

Ultimately, this program is on track to produce more highly qualified technicians into fields where they are greatly needed. The broader impact to employers includes increasing qualified candidates which reduces recruitment costs and time, eliminates needed time off for remedial and skills training, possesses a broader skills base which keeps pace with technology changes, increases productivity by raising workplace standards, gains a competitive edge in the job market, and experiences higher employee retention rates. All these activities will contribute to the long-term outcome of the project, which is to provide the regional workforce with more certified, skilled technicians.

 


Last Modified: 07/22/2022
Modified by: Tanya St Julien
